parts: Name this country, whose myths include gods such as Uzume, Fūjin, and Tsukuyomi in Shintoism .
This mythical person was the first emperor of Japan. This man was assisted by a three-legged bird on his journey to capture Yamato.
This god was the great-grandfather of Emperor Jimmu. Under the orders of Amaterasu, this god brought a jewel, mirror, and sword to Japan in order to restore it.
Name this 2014 Ta-Nehisi Coates article in which he examined the differences in black and white poverty and home ownership while arguing for the titular concept.
“The Case for Reparations” was published in this magazine currently edited by Jeffrey Goldberg and named for the large body of water near the town where it was founded, Boston.
This second-oldest continuously published literary magazine in the U.S. underwent significant changes in the 1980s under the leadership of editor Lewis Lapham.

Name this quantity that measures a material’s stiffness. For a linearly elastic material, it equals stress divided by strain. This “modulus” is named after a British physicist who also did the double slit experiment.
This quantity equals the negative ratio of transverse strain to longitudinal strain, and describes how materials expand in the direction perpendicular to a compressive force.

The true strain of a deformed material is measured with respect to the deformed cross-sectional area, in contrast to this other kind of strain, which is measured relative to the initial cross-sectional area.

answers: Black and Tans [or The Royal Irish Constabulary Special Reserve; prompt on Royal Irish Constabulary]
Theobald Wolfe Tone [or the Wolfe Tones]
parts: Dominic Behan’s song “Come Out Ye [these people]” asks them to tell their wives “...how the IRA made you run like hell away / from the green and lovely lanes of Killeshandra.” This notoriously brutal auxiliary force opened fire at a Gaelic football match at Croke Park.

A prolific Irish rebel music band is named for this revolutionary, who helped found the United Irishmen. This Protestant was executed for leading the 1798 Irish Rebellion with the support of the French First Republic.
The sporting anthem “The Fields of Athenry” describes a man shipped to the Australian penal colony for having “stole Trevelyan’s corn” during the 1840s famine caused by the failure of this crop.
Name this class of diuretics with a bicyclic molecular structure that contains adjacent sulfur and nitrogen atoms. HCTZ is one of these drugs.
Thiazides primarily work on the sodium-chloride symporter on this part of the kidney responsible for final sodium reabsorption before reaching the collecting duct. It occurs after the loop of Henle.

Thiazides can also be used to treat kidney stones caused by accumulation of this ion. This ion’s levels in the blood are increased by parathyroid hormone triggering breakdown of bone, and vitamin D helps absorb it.
Name this Italian composer, who wrote brief poems as footnotes to the violin concertos which comprise his series The Four Seasons.
The outer movements of Vivaldi’s Double Concerto for Two Mandolins are structured around these repeating sections, which were commonly used as instrumental refrains in baroque operas and concertos.

The harmony in Vivaldi’s concertos is sustained by this type of accompaniment, which was ubiquitous in the baroque era and typically consisted of an instrumental bass line written in figured bass notation, so a keyboard or lute player could realize chords above it.

answers: secondary qualities [do not prompt on or accept partial answers]
parts: Identify these concepts outlined in An Essay Concerning Human Understanding. They are said to include colors, sounds, and tastes.
The division of material qualities into primary and secondary types was described by this philosopher in the second book of his Essay Concerning Human Understanding.

Locke holds that since an exact collection of secondary qualities would not give us the essence of a thing, complex ideas of substances have this feature. Locke used this term to refer to ideas that do not perfectly represent their archetypes.

answers: Poèmes saturniens [or Saturnine Poems or Saturnian Poems or Poems under Saturn]
parts: Name this poem, which describes a song that “blends with the moonlight, / With the sad and beautiful moonlight.”
This French author and lover of Arthur Rimbaud (“ram-BOUW”) wrote “Clair de Lune.”

Melancholia and Paysages tristes (“pay-ZAWJ TREEST”) are two sections of this first poetry collection by Verlaine. Its prologue says “Every soul depends upon a star” and dedicates the book to those born under a “planet / to the necromancer dear.”

answers: Polisario Front [or Frente Polisario; or FRELISARIO]
parts: Name this ethnic group that has fought for independence in the Western Sahara. This Hassaniya Arabic-speaking ethnic group descends from the Yemeni Beni Hassan tribe and local Berbers.
This organization proclaimed the Sahrawi Arab Democratic Republic and fought a war in Western Sahara to control the territory after the Spanish withdrawal in 1976.

In the 1975 Madrid Accords, Mauritania agreed to split Western Sahara with this North African kingdom, which built a 2,700 kilometer sand berm to separate its “Southern Provinces” from Polisario Front-territory.

answers: the Holy Trinity [accept The Hospitality of Abraham; or any answer mentioning angels and Abraham, as that is what is actually depicted in Rublev’s version]
parts: Name this scene that takes up the center of a deesis (“DEE-es-is”). This scene shows Jesus holding the New Testament with his left hand and making a blessing gesture symbolizing the letters IC XC with his right hand.

The image of Christ Pantocrator appears in many of these religious artworks that are venerated in the Eastern Orthodox Church. They were destroyed during two periods in Byzantine history in a movement named after them.

Andrei Rublev’s icon of this subject is at the Tretyakov Gallery and has a cup at its center. An illusionistic barrel vault frames the central group in Masaccio's version of this subject, which has a memento mori at the bottom.

answers: gerade and ungerade [or g and u]
parts: Name this molecular geometry exemplified by hemiacetals and methane. The angle between bonds in this geometry is about 109.4.

Molecules with octahedral geometries also have d-orbitals split into two levels, but they undergo this effect more strongly in order to break the degeneracy of their d orbitals. In this effect, bonds along the z-axis are elongated.
The Jahn-Teller effect breaks symmetry to allow transitions between two states of the same parity with respect to an inversion center. Those states are given these two names, name both.

In “Threat Level Midnight,” an episode of “The Office,” Michael’s cinematic spy alter ego leads the gang in this dance, whose moves include “you meet new friends, you tie some yarn, and that’s how you do” this dance.

On this TV show, the titular character shows everyone how to do a dance in which you “twist yourself around and give a great big lunge” while dancing alongside Pearl, a whale who in that episode is the prom date to this show’s titular character.
The cast of The Rocky Horror Picture Show performs this line dance, which is “just a jump to the left, and then a step to the right”.

answers: Barbara Undershaft [or Major Barbara; prompt on Undershaft]
parts: Name this character, who becomes disillusioned with the Salvation Army after they accept a large donation of money from her father’s arms manufacturing business.
Major Barbara is the title character of a play written by this author of Arms and the Man and Pygmalion.

Barbara’s mother Lady Britomart contacts her estranged husband for money after discussing the family’s finances with this other character, who is later disinherited from his father’s business because he is not a foundling.

Name this candidate who debated the wealthy JFK in the nation’s first televised presidential debate. This politician proclaimed his innocence in the Checkers speech and resigned the presidency after Watergate.

This historian of American conservatism uses the Orthogonian-Franklin metaphor to stress Nixon’s hatred for elites in his biography Nixonland. This historian chronicled Nixon’s fall and Reagan’s rise in The Invisible Bridge.
Perlstein’s first book Before the Storm discusses the rise of this arch-conservative. This senator laid the groundwork for the Reagan Revolution in his 1960 book The Conscience of a Conservative.
Name this ballerina, who in 2015 became the first African-American woman to be named principal dancer of American Ballet Theatre.

In 2018, Copeland took to social media to defend herself from critics who called her an “embarrassment” for omitting steps in her dual role as Odette and Odile in a performance of this ballet with music by Tchaikovsky.
In the sequence for which Copeland was ridiculed, Odile is required to execute 32 of these turns, which usually consist of a pirouette along with a whip of a raised leg.

In the Hindu tradition, Makara is occasionally depicted as a river dolphin ridden by the divine personification of the Ganges, Ganga. Ganga was married to this king of Hastinapura until she left him after killing 7 of their children.
The fingers of a goddess from this myth system were chopped off and became seals and whales after her father Anguta tried to throw her off of a boat.
The Encantados are magical river dolphins found in this South American river. They turn human at night in order to seduce and impregnate other humans.

answers: corundum [prompt on BUT DO NOT REVEAL ruby or sapphire]
parts: Name this mineral which defines a hardness of 9 on the Mohs scale.

Generally, any corundum that does not have a red color is referred to as this gemstone, although this gemstone is traditionally blue. A common-type of laser contains this gemstone doped with titanium ions.
Just as corundum ranks highly on the Mohs scale of scratch hardness, it also ranks highly on the Vickers scale, which measures this kind of hardness.

Pytheas hailed from this Mediterranean port settled by colonists from the Anatolian city of Phocaea. This city competed with the Roman colony of Narbo Martius after the establishment of the province of Transalpine Gaul.
Pytheas traveled to this island and was the first to write its name, probably transliterating from the Welsh word for it. He described this island’s three corners as Kent, Cornwall, and Orkney.
Diodorus Siculus relates that Pytheas described the mining of this metal in Cornwall, which reached Europe by way of the port of Ictis and then down the Rhone River to Massalia.

answers: London School of Economics and Political Science [or LSE]
parts: Name this university whose social anthropology department has had full-time faculty members like David Graeber, Maurice Bloch, Charles Gabriel Seligman, and Raymond Firth.

LSE endowed this man as the first Chair of Social Anthropology partly for his studies of people on islands off the coast of New Guinea. This Polish anthropologist is best-known for his book Argonauts of the Western Pacific.

E.E. Evans-Pritchard, a student of Malinowski, took a structural-functionalist approach in his works about this second most populous Nilotic ethnic group inhabiting South Sudan. They have recently been involved in civil wars with their fellow pastoralists, the Dinka.
Name this Oyinkan Braithwaite novel, longlisted for the 2019 Booker Prize, in which the nurse Korede covers up the frequent murders of her younger sibling Ayoola.

Guyanan author E. R. Braithwaite is most famous for this autobiographical novel about an ex-RAF pilot who wins the respect of students in an East End school. This novel was made into a Sidney Poitier movie.
Kamau Braithwaite, a poet from Barbados, often uses customized, futuristic fonts in his “Sycorax video style,” named after the mother of Caliban from this work.
